title: Between 5 February 2021 and 31 October 2021, will anti-government protests in Russia result in five or more fatalities?
preds: Nothing in aftermath of Duma elections

Siberian Inmates Start Mass Hunger Strike Over Deaths Of Two Prisoners, Alleged Rights Abuses - Radio Free Europe / Radio Liberty
https://www.rferl.org/a/russia-prison-mass-hunger-strike/31457897.html
Mon, 13 Sep 2021 07:00:00 GMT
fd535261a17f7222106c36d6ab136900 "Inmates in Russian prisons often launch mass hunger strikes or maim themselves to protest brutality perpetrated by guards or abuses of their rights."

The results of the Duma election did not spark major protests. The protests earlier this year after Navalny was arrested did not lead to deaths despite being relatively large. Five or more fatalities is generally a very high number for Russia in this context. Currently there does not seem to exist the conditions for very major protests, so all in all this seems very very unlikely. "Things can happen" is always true but looking at this case I don't see this happening (subject to revision, stranger things have happened etc).

My estimate is that UR gets 324 seats or so in Duma. Clearly through some fraud as it beats ALL surveys. Will it spark protests? Maybe. Actually, I think it will. But 5 or more fatalities? The only viable opposition is Communists and these are older voters, less "plugged". I doubt that young liberals will join forces with dreadful Communists.  Of course, I can change this forecast at any moment - who would expect Belarus unfolding?

Accusations of election tampering could spark protests in the coming days. However, the 2011 analog suggests such protests might not meet the question's timeline and is unlikely to result in fatalities. I'm maintaining some likelihood for the next week or so as this unfolds.
Short term increase due to upcoming election.
Elections are close but the opposition is quiet. They will not be able to build the momentum of unrest.
Increasing a bit as it seems more likely that protests will follow the election next month.

However, there is currently high probability of  anti-vaccine protest - Russia has highest vaccine hesitancy in the world and new measures are nothing but harsh, or ethnic clashes - since disaporas, especially Turkic(Tatar, Azerbaijani, Uzbek, Cherkes etc) ones are very active now, which in turn grows resistance to them from native Russians (Russkie) . So if you would count these kinds of likely protests, then yes - there is some pretty decent chance some may end in fatalities. But they most likely do not make it into Western mainstream news. Thats why I give it 5%.
I'll leave this at 1% till October, then drop to 0
Protests have calmed a bit and no seeming fatalities so far, so not sure this will keep going unless something dramatic happens

I'm actually surprised that this isn't higher, and 5 deaths really doesn't seem to be that high of a bound. In particular, accidents happen.
For instance, the George Floyd protests have 25 deaths (https://www.wikiwand.com/en/George_Floyd_protests)
Upon learning that there have been no fatalities so far, I go down

5% Russian security forces seem to be competent enough to avoid over use of (fatal) force, and seem to be quick at preempting protests. Also doesn't seem (from where I am sitting) much appetite for that kind of protest.
Dialing down further because summer has started and nobody cares.

The loosening of COVID restrictions will likely bring more protests and those protests could turn violent as did the protests recently in April (https://www.npr.org/2021/04/22/989694331/at-least-1-700-protesters-in-russia-arrested-after-nationwide-anti-putin-rallies). For instance, if Alexei Navalny had died during his hunger strike would that have counted as a protest fatality?

Not exactly related, but: Top Russian doctor at Navalny clinic found after disappearance - The Guardian
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/may/10/top-russian-doctor-at-navalny-clinic-found-after-disappearance
Mon, 10 May 2021 16:56:00 GMT ~~~~ The doctor was accused last year of covering up Navalny’s poisoning with a novichok nerve agent, saying in media interviews that the opposition leader may have instead lost consciousness due to a metabolic disease causing low blood sugar. He had also initially refused to give permission for Navalny to be evacuated to a clinic in Berlin for treatment, a transfer that was eventually authorised by Vladimir Putin. The impasse led to a tense standoff at Omsk’s emergency hospital No 1, where close aides to Navalny said that Russian hospital officials were trying to delay tests that would show Navalny had been poisoned. Murakhovsky has since been promoted to health minister of the Omsk region, drawing criticism from the opposition leader. “If you lie, cheat, are ready to falsify to suit the leadership – then you get a promotion,” Navalny wrote in a tweet last year.

From my (fairly quick) research, there do not appear to be any anti-government protests which have lead to even a single (official) fatality since the establishment of the Russian Federation. (I'm not counting the 93 constitutional crises). [1] [2] Therefore our 'base rate' (ignoring the current heightened tension) has to be quite low - in approx. 30 years, this event has not occurred once, so we'd put an annual probability <3%. We can't really reference a longer time horizon in Russia due to the significant changes in the country (Soviet Unicon => Russian Fed etc.) But another reference point, in the UK, a country that has had a similar political environment for >100 years, I'm not sure if we've had 5 or more fatalities from an anti-government protest in the last 100 years. i.e. base rate UK <1%. Obviously UK and Russia have completely different philosophies to policing and protest, so I wouldn't just naively apply UK's rate either. We're going to have to make judgement here, so let's make a pick of 1.5% for our annual base rate in Russia.  For the approx. 6 months left in the timeframe for the question, that gives us a base line probability of about 0.75%. Let's then add to this the a specific 'event' in respect of Navalny. I think we're going to need a few events to all line up in order for their to be >5 fatalities:
1) Navalny dies within the above time frame (assigned 66% chance)
2) Large protests emerge as a result (99% chance)
3) 5 or more fatalities occur as a result of these protests (5% chance) The 5% chance in the third step is based on their being at least 10 'significant' protests in Russia in recent years (see links at bottom), none of which lead to 5 or more fatalities, so I really don;t think this prob can be assigned to be too high. Multiplying out 1-3 gives overall prob of approx. 3.3% of >5 fatalities from Navalny protests
Adding this to our baseline of 0.75% of other protests gives an overall probability of 4%. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_protests_in_the_21st_century#National
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Protests_in_Russia

There will be more protests, and the government will continue to crack down hard. But accurate numbers would be hard to come by. I'd say >70% but considering disinformation, it needs to be "obvious" from recorded footage, and thus a much lower probability.
I'm deferring to the Russian below.
Adjusting down because while I think it is still likely I probably estimated too high of a base-rate

Raising odds on account of Navalny`s health
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/apr/20/kremlin-plots-major-crackdown-on-navalny-allies-as-he-fights-for-life

With Navalny's health deteriorating and his possible death in the coming months, it would be expected that his passing would result in major protests/riots. In similar authoritarian or semi-authoritarian regimes (Venezuela, Syria, Belarus, etc.) there have been severe government crackdowns on these societal movements to challenge the government, and if Navalny were to enter martyr status, smiliar style protests would likely occur. The only issue could be the Russian government hiding or lying about the deaths, which has already occured with their COVID response (https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/10/world/europe/covid-russia-death.html); however, if the protests were quite large and very public it would be much more difficult for the state to keep the official death toll under 5 if there is a severe police response to marches.
Going marginally up on Navalny's health.
The situation must be assessed from one weekend to the next now.

Navalny seems to be dying right now. Putin has calculated that. There will be large protests and small uprisings. A dictator like Putin must then show what he can do. People will die in protests. That is the logical consequence.

Seems Russian police are tooling up for action: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-politics-navalny-tenders-idUSKBN2BP0NE Still unlikely there are going to be fatalities, but I'd say the chances have increased.

@Anneinak asked med the following question and it has made me once again lower my prediction of the likeliness: “Do you have any idea what the base rate for this is? (How many times this happened last year? or on the average over the last decade?)”
This question made me do some research, but unfortunately I still don't know the exact answer. First of all, I think there is reason to expect that those numbers will not have been made public, as independent investigations have shown that several 100 people died in police custody in 2015 without it being official (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jan/13/200-people-died-in-russian-police-custody-in-2015-says-website). Linking to this, it is clear that we don't know the full picture, however according to the data that I was able to find about fatalities connected to demonstrations there actually appeared to be none. I found some articles from different demonstrations over the last decade, and none of them seem to have reported fatalities in spite of 1000s of arrests and many injured.
2011-2013 protests - https://web.archive.org/web/20131224121337/https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/12/07/russia-update-1-tv-pix-idUSL5E7N73K320111207 and https://www.rferl.org/a/russia_rallies_arrests_opposition_protests/24413923.html
2017-2018 protests - https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/may/05/russian-police-arrest-more-than-200-anti-putin-protesters-siberia Based on this, even if some will die that we will not know about, the reported number of fatalities will most likely be 0.

Based on the excellent comments and insightful analysis from @yagudin, @hoosier2020, @Jayce, and @Terry-Smith, I am forecasting a low probability of five protestor fatalities before November 1.  Authoritarian states in my experience are skilled in avoiding situations that escalate inadvertently to extreme violence resulting in protestor deaths.  I observed a bread riot in Havana in the 1990s and marveled at the ruthless, impersonal yet controlled ferocity of the public order police, who had been trained by Soviet advisors.  Their training and planning allowed them to inflict terrible beatings while not killing anyone as they systematically locked down the block where the riot was happening.  I would assume that same institutional knowledge remains a part of the Russian anti-riot police protocols for today’s protests.  The comment by @yagudin about arresting key leaders before protests and warning potential protest leaders to stay home also rang true in my experience.  That Navalny and his inner circle are calling for non-violence further reinforces my estimate of a low probability.

Russia is a big country and it’s still 7 months until October.  Protests also see to be continuing.  Reducing forecast a bit, but still this threshold on question is quite low especially if something big happens as one protest.  I am assuming that things get reported, they may not!  Tipping point will be how long this goes on and if thousands are being arrested, how long that can be sustained.   https://www.scmp.com/news/world/russia-central-asia/article/3122344/navalny-protests-crackdown-russia-intensifies-10000
https://www.politico.com/news/2021/02/14/russia-navalny-protests-putin-469020

[0] https://novayagazeta.ru/articles/2021/02/17/89270-byl-shvachen-na-poroge-doma-dal-boy
They are not as big as the Belarusian protests which caused about 5 deaths.

Assuming that deaths in any anti-government protests are accurately reported in media outlets, Anti-government protests in Russia in 2011-13 and 2017-18 including 100,000s of people, across many cities, and 1000's of arrests did not result in any officially reported deaths. Current protests seem to be of a similar scale to previous protests, but with much greater violence and the number of injuries and arrests per protestor (almost an order of magnitude higher). This seems to imply a higher likelihood of deaths during protests. Similar protests over the summer in the United States and during the certification of the election results in 2020 and 2021 led to approximately 30 deaths for reference. The current set of protests is also focused at the government's failure to allow parties unaligned with Putin to stand in elections, as opposed to requests for better social conditions as in 2018. Thus, the higher propensity for violence coupled with the more existential nature of the threat to the Putin Regime and the United Russia party implies a much greater likelihood for casualties and deaths.   Sources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011%E2%80%932013_Russian_protests
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017%E2%80%932018_Russian_protests
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Russian_protests
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/23/world/europe/navalny-protests-russia.html
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Floyd_protests

Fatalities become inevitable the longer the protests go on and the heavier the response.

Demonstrations against the government have held by a younger segment amongst the populace. The older the demographic, the more likely the support for the incumbent and popular support is still strong.
The protests would appear to be based on one issue (although that may have been a catalyst) but on a general dissatisfaction with the economy. The older generation remember previous days and hardships and are appreciative of better living conditions today.
The police have been aggressive in their reaction to the demonstrations with graphic beatings and jailing of people but there have been no reported deaths connected with this.
This question is fraught with potentially wrong assumptions. How would the deaths be reported and confirmed?
Does cardiac arrest or death by trauma count? Did any of the demonstrators have the Covid-19 virus?
My suggested answer is that there will be no fatalities attributed to anti-government protests. https://time.com/5936827/russia-protests-alexey-navalny-inequality/ https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-55876033  https://apnews.com/article/russia-pro-navalny-protests-explained-0f2f780d35fd46dec25e265a14f52876  https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/02/04/dissatisfaction-with-putin-surges-among-young-russians-levada-poll-a72835

Interestingly ~50 people have been said to have died in the US protests in 2020, but we have far fewer reported from Russia. Possibly because lethal violence in an authoritarian state is likely to be much more explosive, since it galvanizes the protesters. That said the baseline has to be people who have died in custody, in riots etc and that is more than likely more than 5, so what we are betting on is a de facto reduction in deaths related to protests (am unclear as to what we are looking at - does it have to be in immediate proximity to a protest or does policy custody count?).
Between accidental and aggravated police killings during protest and captured political prisoners, 5 seems low.

This is a tough question. I note that it's not immediately clear how the answer will be "officially" measured. Certainly, state media will have something to say about how deaths are characterized and reported. Unless I see something different, in fact, I'm going to knock my overall estimate of likelihood down just a bit for that reason alone - the chances that we'd know of it are slightly lower given the state of media in Russia. That said, it appears to me that anti-government protests don't have a history of turning fatal, at least as far as international media is concerned. Even during the widespread protests that occurred in 2017-2018 there appears to have been no deaths directly attributable to the protests themselves.  I'm going to leave this low unless I see something a) clarifying the final adjudication method or b) massive changes in the numbers of protestors and/or level of violence.
Unlikely but Putin is arguably under greater pressure than ever.

The crowd feels very "outside view" of the situation in Russia. 
Any forecasters here live in or visit Russia regularly? We'd like to hear from you. We forget that people and situations don't vary as much as we think from the outside perspective.

Should one consider the number 5 fatalities or more to include a combination of "protesters"  and "police" and "at?  T"military" and "private contractors"  or what.  Need to make this clear, please...

Firstly, it depends on how fatalities are defined and what data is used. If fatalities mean any death of anyone connected to the protests, which cannot clearly be explained by health or age, then I think we have reason to suspect at least five casulties. To identify these deaths as well as their cause data independent of Russia would need to be used though.
First of all there is reason to expect that the Russian state would try to poison prominent voices within the anti-governement movement, as there is already reason to believe that they tried with Navalny ( https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/03/23/here-are-ten-critics-of-vladimir-putin-who-died-violently-or-in-suspicious-ways/ ). Further looking at recent years there is several examples of deaths of indivudals in the custody of police ( https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jan/13/200-people-died-in-russian-police-custody-in-2015-says-website ), 
This is all build on the fact that protests are still growing though and that those protesting seem to really mean it ( https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/23/world/europe/navalny-protests-russia.html ). If this were to change this forecast should be amended.
The number of participants is quite different from different sources. I doubt the fatalities would be accurately estimated (definitely not implying the fatalities would be covered).

Not estimating full certainty to account for possibility of a fizzling out phenomenon, but Navalny's statements going out have been so defiant and the masses responding critical enough, that with a Russian administration well bent on imposing its control by force if necessary, this seems likely.
Current protests are already escalating with the reimprisonment of Navalny.  This has been highlighted by the incoming administration already.  Continuing economic instability about energy prices.

Barring a trigger for sudden escalation it's very unlikely the protests will reach a level of this kind of intensity. The far more extensive and deeply rooted Belarusian protests have not resulted in 5 fatalities. The Russia protests represent irritation but few concrete grievances and have little of the urgency that would cause ptetestors to escalate. The chance of fatalities is based on a chance of a local protest having a sharp downward spiral, or a conscious use of massive force by the authorities.

The crowd's 19% seems a bit overstated. Russia, for all the intensity of its protests, does not tend to have them turn deadly.  The last anti-government protest I could find that would have triggered a yes in a similar question was in 1993: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1993_Russian_constitutional_crisis  Belarus had a total of four fatalities from what I could find, so even that may not have triggered a positive resolution if this were about country: https://apnews.com/article/alexander-lukashenko-belarus-europe-265b41751fd044271118295ceab0a91b
Moscow expelled a slew of Diplomats' Over Navalny criticisms' which causes me to think they are conditioning the Diplomatic cadre for more serious events.
Dialing down to 4% on news that oppositions asks people to get off the streets.

The regime knows how to dispel, disperse, divert, detain .. without (another d word) death... even intense demonstrations closer to the election will be managed without fatalities.. a peaceful election win for the regime..

Historical rate should be at least 5 per 100 years. I did not invest time to research, but 1905 for sure, 1917, then probably one more in earily XX century and one in the Soviet times, maybe one in USSR -> RU transition. Should be a bit higher up now with more protests, but I don't think it's high up, because if it would not be for historical rate, I'd score it at 0. So I'll bump up from 5 to 7 because of Navalny, and bump up further to 8 because social media stirs more polarization, there was no social media in XX century.
Depends on ground movement and what may, or may not stoke it in the days to come
One yes, one no, one maybe. Put me at most likely no but not sure.

So far there have been no reported fatalities from the protests. Over the last decade there have been several protests in Russia but there are not any reported deaths. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Protests_in_Russia) The Russian security forces are highly effective at suppressing protests and arresting large amounts of people while not escalating to lethal violence likely due to the significant backlash it would cause. Unless the protests become more violent or the Russian security forces change tactics it is unlikely there will be five or more fatalities.
